æ­ç›Ÿæ³Šä½¢åŠ è¿”ä¸€æ”¯ï¼Œç„¡å¾—å™´æ°´ç”¨é«˜ç‡ˆéƒ½ç®—ã€‚é‚„æ˜¯ç„¡æ”¯è½‰æ³¢æ£é‚„æ˜¯å¥½å±éšªçš„ã€‚å•ä½¢éš»AIï¼Œæœ‰ä¸€å–®ç¢ºèªä¿‚å› ç‚ºç”¨monè½‰éŒ¯æ³¢æ­»äººï¼Œé‚„æœ‰å…¶ä»–å””åŒç„¡æ­»äººæƒ…æ³ã€‚
All Reported Cases Related to Tesla On-Screen Gear Shifter

Based on available reports from NHTSA/DOT databases, media investigations, and Tesla forums (primarily unearthed after the Angela Chao incident), here is a comprehensive list of all known cases and complaints tied to Teslaâ€™s touchscreen gear shifter (introduced in 2021 refreshed Model S and Model X, and later variants). These include incidents with and without injuries, near-misses, and general complaints. Note that many complaints lack full specifics (e.g., exact dates or models) due to how they are aggregated in databases. Iâ€™ve grouped them by type for clarity, and all are from post-2021 models unless specified. No additional deaths beyond Chao were found, and NHTSA has not issued a recall specifically for this feature as of August 2025.

Specific Incidents with Details

1. 2024: Fatal Accident (Angela Chao)

â€¢ Model: 2020-2022 Tesla Model X SUV (refreshed with touchscreen shifter).

â€¢ Description: While attempting a three-point turn (K-turn) on a Texas ranch, Chao accidentally swiped for Reverse instead of Drive on the touchscreen, causing the vehicle to back over an embankment and into a pond. She had previously told friends she mixed up gears multiple times and called them in panic as the car submerged. The windows were unbreakable underwater, and doors were hard to open without power.

â€¢ Outcome: Death by drowning; rescue attempts failed, and the vehicle was fully submerged by the time help arrived (24 minutes later). This incident prompted media to review NHTSA complaints.

â€¢ Source: NHTSA investigation and media reports.

2. 2022: Near-Miss at Stoplight

â€¢ Model: Tesla Model Y (with touchscreen shifter).

â€¢ Description: Driver accidentally put the car in Reverse while waiting at a stoplight. They flicked the right-hand gear stalk (in older models, but complaint ties to shifter confusion) to disengage Autopilot, which engaged Reverse; they pressed the accelerator without the brake, nearly backing into the car behind. They attributed it to relying on Autopilot for braking and the unintuitive design.

â€¢ Outcome: No collision or injuries; narrowly avoided by quick correction.

â€¢ Source: DOT/NHTSA complaint database.

3. 2022: Minor Parking Lot Collision

â€¢ Model: Unspecified (post-2021 Tesla with touchscreen shifter, likely Model S or X).

â€¢ Description: Driver failed to shift to Drive, remained stuck in Reverse due to swipe confusion, and hit a parked vehicle at low speed.

â€¢ Outcome: Minor property damage; no injuries reported.

â€¢ Source: DOT/NHTSA complaint database.

Forum-Reported Near-Misses (2022)

These are anecdotal from Tesla ownersâ€™ forums, often tied to the same design confusion but not formal NHTSA complaints:

â€¢ Accidental Reverse Shifts (3 Times in 2 Years): Unspecified model; owner reported mistakenly shifting to Reverse instead of Drive three times over two years. No accidents or injuries.

â€¢ Near-Accident Due to Reverse Confusion: Unspecified model; owner â€œjust nearly had an accidentâ€ while trying to engage Reverse. Another user responded with a similar experience in their first month of ownership. No injuries or collisions.

Aggregated NHTSA/DOT Complaints (2019-2023, ~20 Total; 12 Specific to Reverse/Gear Shifter)

â€¢ Number and General Description: About 20 complaints over five years (primarily Models 3, S, Y from 2015-2023, but focused on post-2021 touchscreen models). Of these, 12 relate directly to the reverse function/touchscreen shifter:

â€¢ 7 complaints about the confusing design (e.g., swiping up/down leads to wrong gear selection, like Drive when intending Reverse or vice versa).

â€¢ 5 complaints about vehicles switching between Drive and Reverse without warning (possibly software-related).

â€¢ Outcomes: No injuries, deaths, or crashes reported in these aggregated complaints; mostly near-misses or frustration during maneuvers like parking or turns. Specifics like exact dates/models are not publicly detailed beyond the examples above. These span various scenarios, including low-speed operations where tactile feedback is missed.

No other widespread or additional specific cases (e.g., from lawsuits, recalls, or international reports) were identified in the searched sources. NHTSA has received broader touchscreen complaints (e.g., failures affecting visibility or controls), but these are not directly tied to the gear shifter unless specified. If more complaints emerge, NHTSA could investigate further, as it has for other Tesla features.
